No demolition, site clearance or building operations shall be commenced until tree protection to the standards set out in BS5837: 2005 "Protection of Trees on Construction Sites" (figures 4 and 5) has been erected around the trees shown on the approved drawings as being retained on the site. The fencing is to be not less than 1.5 metres in height and shall enclose either:-(a) the area described by the limit set out in Table 1 orA16(b) a radius as set out in Figure 2 of BS 5837: 2005, or alternatively(c) such an area as may have previously been approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.Such tree protection shall be maintained during the course of development, and no storage, site structures, parking or any other operation shall be permitted within the area thereby protected. Within the protected area:(a) levels shall not be raised or lowered in relation to the existing ground level,(b) no roots shall be cut, trenches dug, or soil removed or drains and services laid,(c) no buildings, site huts, roads or other engineering operations shall be constructed or carried out,(d) no vehicles shall be driven over the area,(e) no materials or equipment shall be stored. and the destruction by burning of any materials shall not take place on the site or adjoining land unless the fires are at a minimum distance from the protected area of 6.00 metres.Reason: To prevent unnecessary damage occurring to the trees during building operations, thereby safeguarding the visual amenities of the site in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.The Development Plan comprises:The London Plan 2021;RBK Core Strategy 2012;Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008; and,The South London Waste Plan 2022.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Consultations3 no surrounding properties were notified  of the proposed development. No  letters of representation were received.  RBK Environmental Health Officer - no objection to proposed development Recommended planning conditions.Proposal The application seeks full planning permission for refurbishment works including fenestration alterations and cladding to the front and rear elevations. New roofing to main house incorporating insulation. Installation of solar panels and enlargement of rooflight in top flat roof. Erection of single storey rear garden studio with green roof. Installation of heat pump  to front gardenApplication SiteThe  site comprises a mid  terrace dwelling within a modernist 1960s terrace block. The application site  resides within Kingston Hill/ Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character. Planning Assessment  The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Impact on heritage assets- Fire Safety DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale , appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. The existing dwelling is a  two storey building residing within a modernist style terrace block with a flat roof.Refurbishment works are proposed to both the front and rear elevations as well as the roof. In terms of the front elevation,  the existing UPVC windows are to be replaced with composite clad timber windows and a new timber front door with a glazed side panel would replace the existing . The existing painted timber cladding, clay hung tiles and buff/ grey brickwork would remain. In terms of the rear elevation,  the existing UPVC sliding  doors at ground floor level are to be replaced by aluminium framed sliding door. At first floor level, the  existing UPVC windows would  be replaced by aluminium  framed sliding window.   The existing painted timber cladding to be replaced by oiled timber cladding. External folding timber shutters for the windows are to be introduced at first floor level  together with an external timber frame.The existing flat roofing felt of the dwelling is to be replaced with  warm roof insulation flat roofing membrane (grey coloured).The existing  3nos rooflights  are to be removed and 3nos circular rooflights to be introduced.   The proposal also includes  the provision of  PV solar panels to be positioned  on the flat roof.  Officers note the submitted proposed roof plan is an indicative drawing and no definitive details have been provided in respect of dimensions and model of the PV Solar Panels and consequently the number of panels to be accommodated on the roof. Further details would need to be provided by way of a  discharge of a  planning condition for review and approval by the Local Planning Authority. The proposal also includes the provision of a garden room to be positioned at the end of the rear garden. It would measure depth of 3.2m and width of 5.9m with a flat roof eaves height of 2.5m.  The garden room would be constructed from vertical oiled timber cladding. The front elevation would present an external door and a single fixed glazed window. The rear elevation would also provide rear access.   A native wildflower green roof is proposed. Within the context of the existing built form on site  and the capacity of the rear garden, it is considered that the proposal for a garden room would appear as a proportionate and subordinate addition to the main dwelling and would be acceptable from a character and design perspective. A heat pump  is also proposed which would be positioned in the corner of the front garden  behind the existing front boundary wall.     Overall the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impact on the character or appearance of the areas as a result of the proposals. Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  The standalone air source heat pump  is to be positioned in the  front garden  behind the existing front boundary wall. To safeguard the amenities of the occupiers of the neighbouring properties, RBK Pollution Control have recommended  the inclusion of  a planning condition  to control the rating level of the noise determined by the plant.Given the scope of the overall proposed development and the  proportionate and subordinate nature  of the proposed development and its siting in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. Impact on heritage assetsParagraphs 195 to 208 of the NPPF (December 2023) set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.Paragraph 209 of the NPPF (December 2023)  states the effect of an application on the significance of a non designated heritage asset should be taken into account in determining the  application. In weighing applications that directly or indirectly affect non designated heritage assets, a balanced judgement will be required having regard to the scale of any harm or loss of the significance of the heritage asset.Officer comment:  The application site falls within Kingston Hill/ Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character, a designated non heritage asset.  Within the context of the existing built form and noting the  assessment above,  it is considered that the proposal would not have any adverse impact on the character and appearance of the area and would not harm the significance of the Kingston Hill/ Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character . Fire safety London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation  assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12 (A). the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons. Officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal--- Informatives ---Positive and ProactiveIn dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.Building RegulationsYour attention is drawn to the need to comply with the relevant provisions of the Building Regulations, the Building Acts and other related legislation.  These cover such works as  - the demolition of existing buildings, the erection of a new building or structure, the extension or alteration to a building, change of use of buildings, installation of services, underpinning works, and fire safety/means of escape works.  Notice of intention to demolish existing buildings must be given to the Council's Building Control Service at least 6 weeks before work starts.  A completed application form together with detailed plans must be submitted for approval before any building work is commenced.Party Wall ActThe Party Wall Act 1996 requires a building owner to notify, and obtain formal agreement from, any adjoining owner, where the building owner proposes to:- carry out work to an existing party wall;- build on the boundary with a neighbouring property;- in some circumstances, carry out groundworks within 6 metres of an adjoining building.Notification and agreements under this Act are the responsibility of the building owner and are quite separate from Building Regulations, or Planning Controls.  The Building Control Service will assume that an applicant has obtained any necessary agreements with the adjoining owner, and nothing said or implied by the Council should be taken as removing the necessity for the building owner to comply fully with the Party Wall Act. Further information and advice is to be found in "The Party Walls etc. Act 1996 - Explanatory Booklet".Property BoundariesYour attention is drawn to the fact that planning permission does not override property rights, and that if your proposal involves construction on or near the site boundary then you should take appropriate steps to ensure that you have correctly identified the position of the boundary, that you do not build over it, and that any works which affect a neighbours property in any way have the benefit of the appropriate agreement from that landowner. Failure to undertake the above steps may leave you liable to legal action by neighbouring landowners. If you require further information or advice, you should consult a solicitor.Consistency of PlansReasonable efforts have been made to check that the plans submitted for the purposes of this planning application are consistent from one to the next, and that the development hereby approved can be implemented in accordance with all of the plans submitted. Should it transpire that this is not possible and that your plans are flawed, please be clear that it may be impossible to implement this permission, and that any development undertaken which relies on this permission may be unauthorised and subject to enforcement action if expedient.Construction Site NoiseWhen undertaking demolition and/or noisy building work, please be considerate to your neighbours and do not undertake work before 8am or after 6pm Monday to Friday, before 8am or after 1pm on a Saturday or at any time on Sundays or Bank Holidays.  You are advised that the Council does have formal powers to control noise and nuisance under The Control of Pollution Act 1974, the Clean Air Acts and other relevant legislation, and that any works undertaken which impact unreasonably upon the surrounding area may be subject to action by the Council's Environmental Health Department.Definition of Approved in WritingWhere reference is made within the decision notice to a condition applying 'unless otherwise agreed in writing with the local planning authority', please be aware that only a formal application under section 73 or 96a of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (As Amended) is acceptable as a method of said written agreement.Ground Level / Base LevelUnless clearly specified otherwise, the base of the development shown on the approved plans is taken to be external ground level, and not a Damp Proof Course or Internal Finished Floor Level. The external ground level is expected to remain consistent before and after construction of the approved development unless specified otherwise on the approved plans.Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal

The application is made pursuant to Section 96A of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended), which concerns non-material amendments to planning permission. Under Section 96A, a change may be made to any planning permission, including through the imposition of new conditions or the removal/alteration of existing conditions, if the local planning authority is satisfied that the change is not material. In deciding whether a change is material, a local planning authority must have regard to the effect of the change, together with any previous changes made under this section, on the planning permission as originally granted. The National Planning Practice Guidance states that there is no statutory definition of 'non-material'. This is because it will be dependent on the context of the overall scheme - an amendment that is non-material in one context may be material in another. The judgement on 'materially' in any particular case is one of fact and degree.The application seeks to amend the approved scheme The application is made pursuant to Section 96A of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended), which concerns non-material amendments to planning permission. Under Section 96A, a change may be made to any planning permission, including through the imposition of new conditions or the removal/alteration of existing conditions, if the local planning authority is satisfied that the change is not material. The site comprises a ground floor flat within a semi detached dwelling located to the south of Vale Crescent, Kingston Vale, and adjoins the playing fields and open space forming part of  Wimbledon Common.The site lies within the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character, which is a non designated heritage assetThe site is not subject to any other land use designations. 11 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and 8 objections (from 5 postal addresses)  have been received on grounds relating to:Loss of light to living room and kitchenInappropriate size and design, detract from uniform appearanceNoise and disturbanceLoss of privacyImpact on parking and of use of shared drivewayWaste managementStructural integrityMatters relating to the repair and maintenance of the application propertyImpeding access for maintenance of property aboveDisturbance and issues surrounding construction Planning History23/00400/FUL Permission refused  18 April  2023 for the erection of a 6m deep single storey rear extension, refused on grounds relating to  design and appearance, and impact on residential amenity.The key areas of assessment are: - Design and Heritage;- Neighbour amenity; and  - Fire Safety.Design and HeritagePolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Policy Guidance 33 of the Residential Design Guide SPD relates to  single storey rear extensions, which should be designed so that they appear proportionate and subordinate to the host building. It states that  extensions should not normally exceed 3-3.5m in depth, also that a pitched roof  should not normally exceed 4 m in height                                                                                                                Heritage: Paragraphs 200 to 209 of the NPPF (2023) set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.Parapgraph 209 states that "The effect of an application on the significance of a non-designated heritage asset should be taken into account in determining the application. In weighing applications that directly or indirectly affect non-designated heritage assets, a balanced judgement will be required having regard to the scale of any harm or loss and the significance of the heritage asset".Officer comment:The site is located within  the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character (SASC), which is a non designated heritage asset.  Four major elements make up and contribute to the character of this SASC:-(1) Open spaces: This area is particularly well provided with a number of large public and private open spaces, which are semi rural in nature. It includes part of Richmond Park and three golf courses, as well as numbers of playing fields and sports grounds. Richmond Parkand the golf courses are particularly attractive open spaces consisting of rolling grassland with many mature trees and shrubs.(2) Topography: An important part of the character of the SASC is that it is situated on the slopes of Kingston Hill and Coombe Hill, which enhances its visual interest and often affords panoramic views of the Borough and beyond. In addition Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill is a prominent landmark when viewed from many parts of the borough, especially the North of Kingston and New Malden from which it provides a pleasant wooded backcloth. Kingston Hill is also viewed to advantage from the top of Roehampton Vale in Wandsworth LB.(3) Buildings: The majority of houses are detached, substantially large and are generally built at much lower densities than in most other parts of the Borough. Although a majority of houses are not of particular architectural or historical interest a significant number are of townscape importance, including a considerable number of Victorian mansions, some of which are listed (many of which are located in the Kingston Hill and George Road L.A.S.C.'s)(4) Landscaping and gardens: Most gardens in the SASC contain substantial numbers of trees (many protected by TPOs) and shrubs which often screen buildings from public view that it is the landscape rather than the houses which is the dominant feature of the area. In addition some of the larger houses have grounds running into many acres. Another factor in enhancing the character of the area is that most of the gardens have a very clearly defined means of enclosure, whether by hedge, wall or fence.The proposal is for the erection of a single storey  rear extension with roof constructed in aluminium panels  anthracite in colour, with obscure glass panels.  The extension extends 4.7 metres in depth,  with a pitched roof. It is of reduced depth compared with the previously refused scheme (which was 6m in depth) and is shown to align  with the  back wall of the kitchen. The established rear building line of this group of houses is relatively uniform. By aligning with the existing building footprint, the proposed extension  would remaon proportionate to the host building and  woul dnot detract from  the character and appearance of the area and this part of the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character.  The  impact on the heritage asset would be neutral.  Conclusions on Design and HeritageAs such, the proposal is in compliance with Policy D3, HC1 of the London Plan (2021) and Policies CS8, DM 10, DM11 and DM12 of the Core Strategy (2012) and Residential Design Guide SPD (2013).AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Policy Guidance 33 of the Residential Design SPD sets out specific guidance when designing a single storey rear extension.Depth:- If the neighbouring house is set at a lower level the depth of the extension should be reduced- If the neighbouring property has a different rear building line then the depth of the extension could be increased- In all cases at least 50% of the rear garden should remain- Extensions should generally not exceed 3-3.5m in depthHeight:- a flat roof should not exceed 3m in height- a parapet roof should not exceed 3.3m in height- a pitched roof should not exceed 4m in heightPolicy Guidance 17 and 32  of the Residential Design SPD  are also relevant  to the assessment of this application and relate to the 45 degree rule and states that The Council applies the '45 degree rule' in assessing development proposals. New buildings or extensions to existing buildings should not encroach on a line drawn at an angle of 45 degrees from the midpoint of the closest window to a habitable room in a neighbouring property.Officer Comment:The proposed extension is sited along the shared boundary with 73/75 Vale Crescent.  The extension extends approximately 4.7m beyond the rear elevation of the adjoining building, and is set at a raised level with a 3m wall running the length of this shared boundary. The neighbouring  property is of a mirrored arrangement and  has windows on the main wall and  in the rear projecting wing directly facing the proposed extension. Given the  depth and height of the extension, the proposal is considered overbearing for this ground floor  neighbour and would give  rise to an unreasonable loss of outlook and increased sense of enclosure to  habitable room windows within the ground floor flat at No 73 serving the living room and kitchen.With regard to daylight and sunlight, the neighbouring building has a large rear window at the ground floor, and a kitchen window within the projecting wing, which appears to be a similar arrangement to the application site. Whilst detailed drawings have not been provided to show the positioning of neighbouring windows, Officers have undertaken a 45 degree test and consider  that the extension is likely to interrupt the midpoint of the (living room) window on the plan and elevation test. For this reason, it is considered that the proposal would also result in an undue loss of daylight and sunlight to this neighbour.The proposal is in conflict with the Residential Design Guide in terms of its depth. The proposed extension is considered to result in an undue loss of amenity to neighbouring residential occupiers, in conflict with Policy DM10 of the RBK Core Strategy (2012) and Residential Design Guide SPD (2013).Fire Safety AssessmentLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer Comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the road layout out would allow a  fire appliance  outside the site and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.Other Issues:The proposal would provide for additional accommodation as part of the existing flat.  Whilst objections have been received on grounds of disturbance, it is not considered that the proposed extension would result in any unreasonable level of noise or disturbance over what would be expected in a residential area.Issues relating to  building maintenance, structural stability etc are covered under separate legislation.Overall the development is considered to be in conflict with the development plan and as such, planning permission is recommended for refusal.

The site comprises a semi-detached dwellinghouse.13 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representation has been received.Relevant Planning History- 23/02322/HOU - Demolition of rear extension and conservatory, and erection of single storey side and rear extension. Changes to side fenestration. Granted on 25.10.2026 - 23/01005/HOU -Demolition of lean-to extension and conservatory and erection of single storey rear extension with part first floor extension. However, the proposed ground floor extension solely would not be visible from the street and would not be incongruouswith the prevailing pattern of development in the immediate surrounding area.In regard to the first floor extension, officers acknowledge that the applicant has opted for a flat roof in order to address concerns raised regarding excessive scale in the previously refused application (ref:23/01005/HOU). However, the reduction in overall height and design of the proposed roof it wouldstill not be acceptable due to the limited scale of the dwelling and plot, therefore, the first floor extension would still appearing excessive in scale. First floor extensions on the boundary of a semi-detached property are generally unacceptable and will normally be resisted as mentioned in Policy Guidance 34, of the Residential Design SPD. Overall, the proposed first-floor extension in conjunction with the ground-floor extension would be a bulky addition and at odds with the host dwelling and the wider area. Therefore, it is considered that there would be an adverse impacton the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officers Comments: Officers have assessed the impact on daylight/sunlight of the proposed rear/side extension. The assessment demonstrates that the depth and siting of the proposed extensions in relation to neighbouring property No.62 Worthington Road would adversely affect their amenities by reason of overbearing appearance and loss of daylight to their closest ground floor principal habitable room window (reception room).Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A). For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would not be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Officer ReportApplication SiteThe site comprises a detached dwelling .The site is not subject to any particular designations or environmental constraints.Proposal Demolition of an existing garage and rear conservatory, erection of a x2 double storey side extensions and a part two storey/ part single storey rear extension. Fenestration alteration and new external door.Consultations17 properties were notified of the proposal.  Two representations have been received with comments summarised as follows:- The proposal would result in loss of light/sunlight in relation to adjoining properties- Excessive height or bulk of buildings- Access or traffic problems- Noise- PrivacyOfficer comment: The above concerns will be addressed with this assessment.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings- Highway Safety- Fire SafetyCharacter and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed two storey side extensions would be set back from the front elevation by approximately 500mm. The proposed width of the extensions would be less than 50% of the width of the existing dwelling. It is noted that the proposed roofs would not be set down from the existing roof ridge by recommended 500mm, however considering the proposed roof design, it is considered that the side extensions would appear in-keeping with the host dwelling. As such this element of the proposal would be in general compliance with Policy 36. The proposed part single part two storey rear extension, given its scale and siting is considered to appear as proportionate addition to the host dwelling and the surrounding area. Officers note concerns raised with written representations regarding the scale of the proposal, however given the generous size of the plot, the proposed separation distances, siting of the proposal and its design, it is considered to be in-keeping with the surrounding area and the existing street scene that contains various style and scale properties. Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: Officers note comments received within written representations regarding the potential loss of daylight/sunlight in relation to the adjoining properties as the result of the proposal.However, given the siting of the proposal and the proposed separations distances, it is considered that the proposal would pass the 45 and 25 degree rule in relation to all the adjoining properties. It is noted that the adjoining property No 3 Regent Road does not have openings to the side elevation. As per submitted plans, all new windows to the side elevations (including the bedroom 4 window) above the ground floor level would be obscure glazed and not openable below 1.7m when measured from the floor level to prevent any undue overlooking. As the proposal would seek to provide a residential extension to an existing residential dwelling Officers consider that there would be no material increase in noise or disturbance for the occupiers of neighbouring properties. It is further noted that the Environmental Protection Act (1990) provides controls to the Council in the event that any noise should occur that could constitute a statutory nuisance. As such, it is considered that the proposed development due to its siting, generous size plot and the proposed scale and design would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Loss of Car ParkingParagraph 115 of the NPPF, 2023 states that development should only be prevented or refused on transport grounds if there would be an unacceptable impact on highway safety, or where the residual cumulative impacts of development are severe. Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 requires development proposals to have regard to local traffic conditions and highway safety and ensure they are not adversely affected. Officer Comment: Despite the loss of the existing garage, it is considered that the hardstanding to the front of the dwelling remains of an adequate size to accommodate at least 2 off street car parking spaces, therefore the proposal would not result in an unacceptable impact on the local highway network.In relation to cycle parking, Officers note that a secure cycle parking could be possibly provided within the existing amenity space to compensate for the loss of the garage. Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Statement, which is considered to be acceptable.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be  in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

The Building Control Service will assume that an applicant has obtained any necessary agreements with the adjoining owner, and nothing said or implied by the Council should be taken as removing the necessity for the building owner to comply fully with the Party Wall Act.
